Headline: Servant Leadership | Agile Transformation | Productivity Development | Sustainable AI | CRM | CPQ | .Net | Cloud First
Comment: Globalisation and liberalisation must be redefined for today‚Äôs realities. Since the 90s, Indians have powered global tech growth, but at what cost? Recent protests in Australia and England, along with Trump‚Äôs remarks, show rising resistance to immigration. Meanwhile, service industries in India exploit cheap labour, luring talent with ‚Äúonsite‚Äù promises that often become long-term migration. Product firms avoid relocating talent abroad, instead building Global Capability Centers here while protecting local jobs. This raises a crucial question: are we truly benefiting, or just undervaluing our expertise? If other nations impose high visa costs and tariffs, why shouldn‚Äôt India enforce fair wages and reject the label of cheap labour? By ensuring better compensation locally, even for those without foreign stints, we can strengthen our position. It‚Äôs time to rethink how India engages with global corporations.

Headline: Founder & CEO, Actionpackd | Your AI Transformation Partner
Comment:
Interesting perspective, but I think this narrative skips some context.

The truth is, the ‚Äúlast generation of Indian engineers‚Äù didn‚Äôt just build America‚Äôs tech backbone - most of them did so as US citizens or permanent residents, not as Indians building for India. The US offered them world-class infrastructure, compensation, networks, and a chance to rise to global leadership and they took it. That opportunity transformed lives, and it‚Äôs disingenuous to gloss over it now.

Yes, India today is a much stronger place to build than the India of the 90s. Yes, inefficiencies here are real opportunities for entrepreneurs. But let‚Äôs not confuse genuine patriotism with convenient timing. The sudden call to ‚Äústay back and build for India‚Äù comes right after the US has raised the cost of immigration. It feels less like destiny and more like narrative-shaping.

People will always weigh trade-offs. For some, the US will still make sense, for others, India will. Both choices are valid. The point isn‚Äôt to guilt people into staying or leaving, but to build ecosystems in India strong enough that staying truly becomes the better option, not just the cheaper or only one.
